ygData.subject: RE: Why I don't play a Warrior
ygData.messageBody:
> ----------
> From: Wayne Sheppard[SMTP:mrwayne@...]
> Reply To: warriors_eq@onelist.com
> Sent: Monday, July 12, 1999 11:45 AM
> To: warriors_eq@onelist.com; eq-warrior@onelist.com
> Subject: [warriors_eq] Why I don't play a Warrior
>
>
>
> Warriors do not suck.....
>
> ...but maybe the people that are playing them are 'sucky' at playing a
> warrior. Yes I did take offense to alot of things you said. Just because
> YOU don't know how to play a warrior or that it was not fun for you does
> not mean they suck. I played a cleric for about 3 levels and decided it
> was too boring for me. I have my opinions, but I do not go to the EQ
> clerics board and list what is boring or why clerics suck. Now, to
> address some of the points you make.
>
>
> How to play a Warrior:
> 1. Hot key Kick/Bash
> Everyone should know about this one.
>
> You forgot slam. While bash is good for those wielding a shield, if
> you did not make a large race warrior, you are going to be at a
> disadvantage. Slam/Bash makes the warrior, and not because it just
> disrupts a spell caster. I will elaborate further down.
>
> 2. Hot key Assist
> It is so important for everyone to attack the same monster. Eliminating a
> damage source helps so much.
>
> You don't need to Assist...the rest of the party needs it. Let the
> warrior pick the target, everyone else assist the warrior.
>
> 3. Hot key Taunt
> This is vitally important for getting monsters off of spellcasters or
> other
> weakened tanks.
>
> Yes I agree with you here. Taunt is vital. However, knowing when to use
> it and NOT to use it is a learned skill. And if the spellcasters in the
> group don't know what they are doing, no amount of taunting is going to
> get that mob off the spellcaster.
>
> That's about all there is to playing a Warrior. Once you master Taunt and
> Assist you have become the best Warrior you will be. Battles are about
> targeting the correct opponent (targeting spellcasters first, using
> /assist...) and keeping critters off the spellcasters (Taunt).
>
> The (large) warriors biggest advantage is the slam while dual wielding or
> wielding a 2 handed weapon. What warrior is going to use a shield? None
> - therefore bash is totally useless to warriors. With Slam, I stun an
> opponent for 2 full seconds, quite regularly. That is two full seconds
> that the creature is not hitting anyone in the group. And in those two
> seconds that is a free hit, which 90% of the time does max damage.
>
> I'd like to be a better player than that. I want to be able to do
> something
> that saves the entire party. I want people to remember me and want my
> skills in the group. As a Warrior, I can be known as a great Taunter, one
> who keeps the spellcasters free to cast. That's about it.
>
> If you want to be a better player then you made the right decision by
> switching classes. Not everyone is made to be a warrior. Its funny
> though, the people that I group with regularly (2 druids, an enchanger,
> and a wizard) have started second characters. All of them melee classes,
> two of them warriors. They see how I play my warrior and the benefits my
> extra hitpoints does and what slam does and want to try it for themselves.
>
>
> When advertising in Unrest looking for a group, I get so many tells I
> can't answer them all. Why? I dual wielding magical weapons and have a
> magical slam - when fighting creatures that are invulnerable to normal
> weapons, my warrior excels. I was soloing scarecrows at level 17 and 18,
> and soloing gargoyles at level 21.
>
> I play a Cleric mainly now. Every battle consists of many decisions that
> may affect the outcome.
>
> A cleric is good for one thing and one thing only - healing - and
> then not as much if you have two druids in your ranks. Nope sorry but the
> cleric is a one dimensional class that any body can start and learn how to
> do it. Heal the person that is lowest on hitpoints when they get below
> the threshhold that is predetermined when you join a party. Cast an
> occasional root and buff and you got what the cleric is good for. I'd
> rather have a druid - they can guarantee escape iin outdoor situation with
> SoW and I don't have to rely on the cleric wasting all his mana on root
> and still have enough to heal me. With SoW I can get away when I know its
> time for me to go - and that only happens if the rest of my group has made
> it away safely. You forgot to mention that in what your warrior needs to
> do.
>
>
> The first decision happens when the puller returns. Did he bring too
> many?
> Should I Root one? Or should I Fear one of the critters away? Is it
> important for me to start casting Direct Damage (on a spellcaster for
> example) or should I conserve mana for Heals?
>
> In a group you should be fighting stuff that is yellow or red to you -
> your root is going to be resisted 7 out of 10 times. Fear the critter?
> Make it run away and come back later after the spell effect runs off?
> Maybe with friends? Dumb idea. Leave the direct damage for the wizard
> and keep to what you do best - healing.
>
> Next I will normally assist one of the tanks for a few rounds. It is my
> job
> to monitor everyone's HP and heal them up when needed. If I heal too much
> too soon, I will draw all the critters onto me. So I must carefully judge
> when and how much to heal. There is also a choice of who to heal. Should
> I
> heal Tank-A who is it half health but only has one critter on him, or
> should
> I heal Tank-B who is at three-quarters health but has three critters on
> him?
> Maybe I should wait a few rounds or do I need to heal right now?
>
> Just heal, thats what a cleric is good for. No other decisions to make.
> If you have good tanks you shouldn't even have to use your staff. As for
> which tank you need to heal, thats simple. THe one that is below their
> health threshhold. For me that would be about half my hit bar, 300 points
> in a multiple mob situation or below 1 and a half bubble in a single mob
> situation.
>
>
> As soon as I have used some mana, I have another choice. Should I
> meditate
> right away or should I continue swinging my staff? Will I need mana for
> an
> extra heal or should I do some immediate damage with combat?
>
> Easy. Meditate so you can heal some more.
>
> Then I have to deal with runners. Should I Root a runner so a tank can
> finish him off or do I need to finish him myself with Direct Damage? Can
> I
> afford the mana for this or should I chase the runner down myself to
> finish
> him off with combat?
>
> Hopefully someone else is in the group that is better with dealing with
> runners. Snare comes to mind. They don't fight back like they do with
> root. And slam mixed with snare works wonders.
>
> Also I must decide when to tank. Clerics can wear good armor and have
> decent HPs. I might need to tank a few rounds to save a Wizard or give a
> Warrior a break.
>
> About the only time a cleric needs to tank is if there are no other tanks
> available. In a high level party thats not going to be the case. Stick
> to the back lines and do what you do best. Heal.
>
> After a big battle where I made several important decisions that saved the
> day for us I realize how important those choices I had to make were.
> Having
> learned to be an effective Cleric made a big difference.
>
> You haven't made any important decisions. You elongated your text to make
> people think there is alot more to healing than there really is. Clerics
> are one of the easiest classes to play. If you get in trouble you can
> gate. Warriors need to learn the area they are in, especially in
> dungeons, because they may need to make a quick escape through the maze of
> tunnels.
>
> Then I think about it from the Warriors point of view. The Warrior did
> Kick, Kick, Kick, Taunt, Kick, Kick, Kick, Taunt, the cleric is getting
> attacked, switch targets, Kick, Kick, Kick, Taunt, Kick, Kick, Kick,
> Taunt,
> runner rooted by cleric, chase runner down, switch targets, Kick, Kick,
> Kick, Taunt.
>
> I hardly ever use kick. Slam works so much better. In a group, I
> shouldn't have to chase down a target. If there is more than one mob
> fighting the party and one of them is on the spell caster, I need to pull
> both of them on me. Harder said than done when you have 3 spellcasters
> running in different directions. I usually have multiple targets that I
> switch between.
>
> Playing a Warrior doesn't compare to a Cleric. As a Warrior, I feel so
> useless. If the battle is going bad, there is nothing I can do but hope
> the
> Random Number Generator starts falling our way. All I can do is soak up
> damage like a sponge, do more combat damage than everyone else and Taunt
> critters off the spellcasters.
>
> Again, thats probably because you don't know how to play a warrior.
>
> A Warrior can learn everything there is to know about his class in one
> day.
> Gaining new levels never changes the strategy a Warrior. Sure they get
> dual
> wield and double attack, but this only increased damage and does nothing
> to
> add new combat choices.
>
> BS - it took me nearly 20 levels to learn how to be a good warrior, and
> there are still things I am learning everyday.
>
> A Cleric takes a long time to master. I feel there is much more for me to
> learn as a Cleric. And every 5 levels I get a new set of spells that need
> to learn to use. I'm sure I'll be learning new tricks all the way up to
> level 50 (if I ever get that far).
>
> BS - like I said before, clerics are a one dimensional class.
>
>
> Don't misunderstand me. Tanks are a very needed part of a party.
> Spellcasters need Warriors up front to take the blows and deal out the
> damage. Warriors are just not my style. The limited options during
> combat
> are not what I am looking for. For many of you, the Warrior is perfect.
> Being able to stand toe to toe with a critter and doing damage with a
> sword
> is exactly what many people want.
>
> Verant's improvements:
> Bezerker Frenzy - happens automatically when low on HP
> More HPs - Lets us take more damage
> More Magic Resistance - Better against spellcasters
> Critical Hits - Randomly more damage
>
> These improvements do make Warriors a better class. But nothing there
> makes
> me want to play them. I would consider playing a Warrior if there were
> more
> active skills. I need a skill that I can choose when to use it, so that
> it
> may make a difference in combat.
>
> I've suggested in the past a Battle Cry skill. This skill, usable once
> per
> day, would increase the AC and Attack Speed of everyone in the party for
> 30
> seconds.
>
> Negates the use of buffs. Basically a lame skill that would only be good
> in a solo situation, if at that.
>
> Another option would be Fighting Styles. Give us an Offensive fighting
> style. This would increase damage or Attacking plus a taunt bonus while
> sacrificing AC and Defense. And we would also want a Defensive fighting
> style. This would boost AC, dodge, and defense with a sacrifice to
> Attacking and damage. It would be very cool if these Fighting Styles
> could
> only be learned through a quest designed for around levels 15-20.
>
> You want a different fighting style, play a monk. Not different enough
> for you, play a ranger. Still not satisfied? Play a pladin.
>
> Give Warriors something to think about in combat. Make it so that
> experienced, skillful Warrior can be better than any newbie Warrior. Give
> them some abilities that would take skill to use effectively. Knowing
> when
> to switch Fighting Styles or use Battle Cry would be something an
> experienced Warrior could learn to do well.
>
> I am a much better warrior after playing for 14 days than I was as a
> newbie. As warriors get higher in level, they become more rounded. A
> warrior at 15 is not the same warrior as he was at 5 (hopefully).
>
> Angarth Bladedancer, Warrior of the 21st Tier
> "Periissem ni periisem"
>
> P.S. You are entitled to your opinion. But when you post garbage like
> this on a place devoted to warriors, you will get some people that love
> their class tear everything you said apart. That said, I wish you luck in
> playing your cleric.
>
>
>
